**Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis**  
• **Frame 1** – Three lanes are visible: a left lane (with a pronounced left‐turn arrow), a center lane in which our camera car is stopped, and a right lane where the pickup truck is. The markings for the camera car’s lane appear to show a combination straight–and–left arrow; there is no right‐turn arrow visible in the center lane.  
• **Frame 2** – The same three‐lane arrangement is clearer. The rightmost lane (with the pickup truck) is the only lane whose markings appear to permit a right turn (though it may also allow through traffic).  
• **Frames 3–5** – The center lane’s pavement markings consistently suggest straight or left possibilities, but not right. Meanwhile, the pickup truck’s lane on the far right is the sole lane positioned for turning right at the corner.  

**Contextual Reasoning**  
No additional lanes open up to the right beyond the pickup truck; the center lane does not show any right‐turn arrows in any of the frames. Standard intersection design would likewise place right turns in that far‐right lane only.  

**Matching to Answer Choices**  
(A single right‐turn lane), (two right‐turn lanes), (three), or (four): the markings confirm just one lane from which a right turn is permitted.  

**Provide the Best Answer**  
<answer>A. 1</answer>
